clinical_study.brief_title: MULTIple Doses of IPTi Proposal: a Lifesaving High Yield Intervention
clinical_study.official_title: MULTIple Doses of IPTi Proposal: a Lifesaving High Yield Intervention

collaborator.agency: Institut de Recherche pour le Developpement
Centro de Investigacao em Saude de Manhica

brief_summary.textblock:
As efforts to control malaria are stalling, and malaria is particularly severe in children U2, it is imperative for countries in Africa with areas of moderate-to-high malaria transmission to implement IPTi through the EPI, with IPTi given with additional EPI contacts to the currently recommended 3 doses, including those in the second year of life.
The MULTIPLY project goal is to improve child survival by decreasing malaria and anaemia burden, as well as vaccine-preventable diseases. Inequities in access will be addressed by delivering the intervention -IPTi-, through the EPI, including mobile-outreach clinics to facilitate access of hard-to-reach populations facing socio-economic and/or geographic barriers. All of this will maximise the delivery and uptake of IPTi to achieve the full potential and effectiveness of the intervention.

detailed_description.textblock:
The African region continues to bear the largest burden of malaria morbidity with more than 215 million malaria cases (94% of the total) in 2019 [1]. The majority of these cases occurred in children under 5 years of age (U5), who also bore the highest mortality burden with 67% of all malaria deaths (over 274,000 children) [1]. It is estimated that about 24 million children, most of them U5, had P. falciparum infection in 2018 in sub-Saharan Africa (SSA) [2].
The latest World Malaria Report indicates that, although the incidence of malaria cases in sub-Saharan Africa (SSA) has declined from 2000 to 2019, these gains have stalled in recent years [1]. Importantly, the age pattern of severe malaria disease and death has not changed; it is still children under 2 years of the age (U2) that bear the brunt. Even in low-to-moderate malaria transmission settings, where older children suffer most malaria episodes, infants have the highest mortality rate.
In the last decades, little changes have been introduced in the armamentarium to prevent malaria in children exposed to the infection that mostly rely on the use of insecticide-treated nets (ITNs). However, despite the wide distribution of ITNs only 52% of pregnant women and children slept under an ITN in 2019 [1]. In the last decade a renewed interest and drive in the use of drugs to prevent malaria led the WHO policy recommendation in 2012 advise seasonal malaria chemoprevention (SMC) in areas of highly seasonal malaria transmission [3]. Over the last years, SMC has been increasingly deployed not only in the initially recommended malaria transmission areas, but also in other endemic settings that do not necessarily meet the agreed criteria for SMC implementation. As the evidence suggests, the currently used malaria control strategies are insufficient to achieve a significant reduction in the malaria burden of disease and death.
In 2010, the WHO recommended IPTi for malaria control in children living in areas with moderate-to-high malaria transmission where resistance to sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine (SP) is low, defined as prevalence of a specific (K540E) resistance-causing gene mutations of 50% or less in the malaria parasite [4]. IPTi consists of the administration of a full therapeutic course of SP (whether or not parasites are present) through the Expanded Programme on Immunisation (EPI) at defined intervals corresponding to routine vaccination contacts at 10 weeks of age with diphtheria, tetanus toxoids and pertussis (DTP)2, 14 weeks with DTP3, and 9 months of age with measles immunisation [4].
Despite that IPTi has been shown to be safe and efficacious in reducing clinical malaria, anaemia and hospital admissions, and to be highly cost-effective since it is delivered through the EPI and uses an inexpensive antimalarial drug SP (0.17 USD / tablet), it has not been implemented to date except in Sierra Leone [5-7]. Reasons for this are unclear although a generalised overoptimistic perception that malaria was under control in many endemic countries, together with poorly supported evidence that IPTi would spread parasite resistance to SP, may be some of the reasons for impeding its implementation.
For too long malaria control has relied on vertical approaches, carried out by a sense of urgency that we could not wait until health systems would develop in endemic countries and thus, new parallel delivery systems would need to be created. Integrated Child Care Management, SMC and ITNs built on that approach. Unlike these activities, IPTi builds on the concept of using an existing and effective delivery platform, the EPI, integrating health services, which is essential to sustainability and equity and a fundamental component of Universal Health Coverage, a flagship of WHO, and will contribute to the Global Technical Strategy for Malaria 2016-2030, "Pillar 1. Ensure universal access to malaria prevention, diagnosis and treatment" [8].
In Sierra Leone, IPTi was introduced in four districts in 2017, followed by its national scale-up in 2018. Undoubtedly, the IPTi programme in Sierra Leone represents a unique opportunity to learn lessons that may apply to other countries where this strategy would be implemented. According to a recent report from the MOH of Sierra Leone, at 9 months of age only a third (32.2%) of the infants had received the three recommended IPTi doses, and of the 52.2% of the children who received the measles vaccination at 9 months of age, only 36.4% of them also received the third dose of IPTi. Thus, even where IPTi is implemented nationwide there are important challenges that need to be addressed to optimise the coverage and the impact of this malaria control strategy, and efforts need to be made to strengthen the supply of, and demand for, EPI.
A frequent concern regarding the use of an antimalarial drug especially if given as monotherapy is the potential development of parasite resistance. The fact that IPTi with SP is only given to a small proportion of individuals, together with the reduction in malaria episodes resulting from the intervention, and that SP is no longer the first-line antimalarial drug in endemic countries, make the likelihood of developing parasite resistance associated to IPTi to below [9]. Moreover, mathematical models predict that IPTi is unlikely to shorten the useful life of the drug or to significantly affect the spread of highly resistant parasites in areas where partial resistance to SP is already established [10, 11]. However, to provide advance warning of increases in drug resistance that may indicate considering replacing SP to an alternative drug for IPTi, implementation of the intervention should be accompanied by monitoring of drug-resistance in some sentinel areas of the country [10]. In Sierra Leone for instance, after one year of national IPTi implementation, there was no evidence of increasing resistance to SP [12].
The prophylactic effect of IPTi provides protection for up to 6 weeks in infants. Therefore, in the currently recommended IPTi scheme, infants are exposed to the infection for about 4 months during a critical period of high susceptibility to harmful effects of the infection. Exploiting additional opportunities to administer IPTi to children in their first years of life could be of great public health interest. In settings where vitamin A deficiency is a public health problem WHO recommends vitamin A supplementation, habitually done through the EPI scheme starting at 6 months of age, at 6 months intervals; thus, the addition of IPTi at 6, 12, 15 and 18 months of age to vitamin A administration would improve malaria prevention during a critical time in the first year of life and expand it into the second. Moreover, the integration of these two interventions might help increase the coverage of vitamin A supplementation, which ranges between 53%-57% in sub-Saharan Africa, and importantly will help reduce the prevalence of anaemia in young children by combining the effect of malaria prevention and of vitamin A on increasing haemoglobin levels [13]. Additionally, in recent years the inclusion of a booster dose of measles immunisation in the EPI, between 15-18 months of age, also offers the opportunity of further expanding malaria protection in the second year of life using IPTi. This is particularly relevant given that severe malaria cases are more prevalent between 1 and 3 years of age in high and moderate transmission areas [14, 15]. By integrating IPTi with EPI contacts, and conducting a social and behaviour change communication (SBCC) campaign to inform the community of the importance of EPI, and the malaria protection afforded by IPTi delivered at the EPI, the demand for EPI is likely to be increased.
Potential adverse effects on the serological response to immunisation of the concomitant administration of SP with routine vaccines were assessed previously demonstrating that there is no negative effect [16]. Additionally, no evidence of adverse interactions between vitamin A and SP concomitant administration exist.

primary_outcome.measure: To introduce, or increase the implementation of the IPTi strategy, delivered alongside EPI contacts in the first two years of life.

secondary_outcome.measure: To assess the operational feasibility of IPTi at health facilities and outreach EPI clinics.
To evaluate the cost and cost-effectiveness of IPTi implementation.
To assess the acceptability (satisfaction, barriers and facilitators) and fidelity of IPTi implementation.

To evaluate the impact of IPTi implementation on the prevalence and incidence of malaria , severe disease, anaemia and overall mortality, as well as on health services integration and quality of care.
To compare prevalence of malaria among U2 children before and after two years of multiple doses of IPTi implementation in project districts.
To compare the coverage of IPTi3 before and after two years of multiple doses of IPTi implementation in the project district of Sierra Leone.
To assess the coverage of IPTi3 after two years of multiple IPTi doses implementation in project districts of Mozambique and Togo.
To monitor the development of SP resistance markers in project areas.
To increase demand for EPI and create it for IPTi in Mozambique and Togo, and increase it in Sierra Leone.
To build capacity and establish an environment to support transition to MOH for scale-up and sustainable IPTi in project countries

To generate and disseminate knowledge to WHO and MOH of project countries to inform recommendations and guidance for IPTi delivery, integrated within national MNCH, NMCP, Nutrition and EPI policy/guidelines.

arm_group.description: A cohort of children (n=250) receiving the Standard of Care (SOC cohort); the definition of SOC varies between study countries: in Sierra Leone, SOC is defined as receiving three doses of IPTi, whereas in Mozambique and Togo, SOC is defined as no IPTi.
A cohort of children (n=250) receiving the MULTIPLY IPTi-SP scheme (MULTIPLY cohort).

intervention.intervention_name: Intermittent preventive treatment of malaria with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine
intervention.description: IPTi will be administered as full therapeutic courses of SP alongside routine EPI immunisations at defined intervals corresponding to vaccination schedules - usually at 10 weeks, 14 weeks, and 9 months of age - to infants living in project districts. Additional doses of IPTi will be administered at 6, 12, and 15 or 18 months of age, coinciding with vitamin A administration and measles booster immunisation. The number of doses of IPTi a child will receive will depend of the EPI schedule in the country, with a maximum of six doses in the first two years of life.
